items.title: AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'json' on userpass.py
items.body:
Hello everyone,

I'm trying this library, and I have to admit that I'm pretty new to it, so maybe I'm doing something wrong.

I want to authenticate to a Vault server using Userpass method.

I created a client without problems, the vault is already unsealed, but I get an error like this:
```
>>> client = hvac.Client(url='MY_SERVER')
>>> client.sys.is_sealed()                                                                                                                                                                                
False 
>>> login_response = client.auth.userpass.login( 
   ...      username="MY_USERNAME", 
   ...      password="MY_PASSWORD"
   ...     ) 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-19-186fe49f4016> in <module>
----> 1 client.auth.userpass.login(username=username, password=password)

~/.virtualenvs/vualt/lib/python3.6/site-packages/hvac/api/auth_methods/userpass.py in login(self, username, password, mount_point)
    138             json=params,
    139         )
--> 140         return response.json()

AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'json'
```

Inspecting the file `userpass.py`, I found that some methods are returned like `response.json()`, and others returned like `self._adapter.post( ... )`. I checked other files and most of the returns are like the second one.

Deleting the `.json()` seems to work.

Is a problem in the library or from by side?

Cheers!

items.title: Add request info to exception objects
items.body:
Hello!

Sometimes it's difficult to figure out what's wrong with Vault ACL or paths inside of it. It would be very useful if `VaultError` objects contained some information about the request (not only about the response as it is now), for example, at least HTTP method and URL.

Thanks for the library!

items.title: kubernetes config does not support issuer
items.body:
Kubernetes config does not support issuer.

Optionally when setting up a kubernetes auth method you can provide an issuer that is check as the issuer on the JWT token, and pem_keys for validating JWTs.

Related: https://github.com/TerryHowe/ansible-modules-hashivault/issues/236

items.title: Test errors during setUpClass leave vault instance running
items.body:
If an integration test fails during a setUpClass call, the resulting vault instance is never terminated.  This causes all subsequent integration tests to fail because they expect to be interacting with an uninitialized vault instance.

For example, this is the first integration test to failure was caused by not having Java installed in my Docker image.  (Related to #529)

```
======================================================================
ERROR: test suite for <class 'tests.integration_tests.api.auth_methods.test_ldap.TestLdap'>
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/hvac/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/suite.py", line 209, in run
    self.setUp()
  File "/hvac/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/suite.py", line 292, in setUp
    self.setupContext(ancestor)
  File "/hvac/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/suite.py", line 315, in setupContext
    try_run(context, names)
  File "/hvac/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/util.py", line 471, in try_run
    return func()
  File "/hvac/tests/integration_tests/api/auth_methods/test_ldap.py", line 22, in setUpClass
    cls.ldap_server = MockLdapServer()
  File "/hvac/tests/utils/mock_ldap_server.py", line 64, in __init__
    'entries': self.ldap_entries,
  File "/hvac/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ldap_test/server.py", line 202, in __init__
    SERVER_PROCESS = run_jvm_server(java_gateway_port)
  File "/hvac/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ldap_test/server.py", line 72, in run_jvm_server
    raise Exception("'java' executable not found in system path!")
Exception: 'java' executable not found in system path!
```

From this point forward, all of the remaining integration tests fail on the following:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/hvac/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/suite.py", line 209, in run
    self.setUp()
  File "/hvac/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/suite.py", line 292, in setUp
    self.setupContext(ancestor)
  File "/hvac/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/suite.py", line 315, in setupContext
    try_run(context, names)
  File "/hvac/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/util.py", line 471, in try_run
    return func()
  File "/hvac/tests/integration_tests/api/auth_methods/test_mfa.py", line 17, in setUpClass
    super(TestMfa, cls).setUpClass()
  File "/hvac/tests/utils/hvac_integration_test_case.py", line 44, in setUpClass
    cls.manager.initialize()
  File "/hvac/tests/utils/server_manager.py", line 109, in initialize
    assert not self.client.sys.is_initialized()
AssertionError: 
```

---

Nose uses and is built on top of the unittest library.  The [documentation for it](https://docs.python.org/2/library/unittest.html#organizing-test-code) has the following tiny blub on the subject:

> If setUp() succeeded, the tearDown() method will be run whether runTest() succeeded or not.

The implication here is that if setUp _didn't_ succeed then tearDown _isn't_ called.  This took me by surprise, but it turns out [I wasn't the only one](https://bugs.python.org/issue5538).

I'll start working on a fix for this.

items.title: Escape/Quote URL Parameters
items.body:
URL placeholders need proper escaping/quoting/encoding to prevent valid names or paths from being misinterpreted.  This is the general case of the related issue #248.

A gist demonstrating the issue can be found here: https://gist.github.com/llamasoft/92f02f7d5b132e9715a2ee8c1f20d5c7

In theory, we should be safe applying `quote(path)` for any field defined as `{path}` and `quote(value, safe="")` for any non-`{path}` fields specified in the [OpenAPI specs](https://www.vaultproject.io/api/system/internal-specs-openapi.html).

- Using `quote(path)` on `{path}`s will prevent characters like `?` or `%` from causing issues while still allowing for `/` to define an actual path location.
- Using `quote(value, safe="")` on non-`{path}` fields will prevent it from being interpreted as anything but a single text value.

items.title: Can't parse dictionnary to create_or_update_secret method
items.body:
**Briefly describe the issue:**

`vault_co.secrets.kv.v2.create_or_update_secret('prod/' + next(iter(server)), secret=secret)` 
is giving me a 
`json.decoder.JSONDecodeError` 
however 
`vault_co.write('secret/prod/' + next(iter(server)), data=secret)` 
is working fine.

**What did you expect to happen?**

`create_or_update_secret` seems to not validate the dictionnary in the `secret` variable, although  `write` does.

**What did happen?**

`create_or_update_secret` failed.

**Please include helpful code examples so we can attempt to replicate (if applicable):**

Here is the variables:

```
next(iter(server)) = Arthur
secret = {'IP': '192.168.1.4', 'User': 'root', 'Password': 'Pa$$w0rd'}
```
Here is the Stacktrace:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 5, in <module>
  File "/opt/rh/rh-python36/root/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/hvac/api/secrets_engines/kv_v2.py", line 124, in create_or_update_secret
    return response.json()
  File "/opt/rh/rh-python36/root/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/requests/models.py", line 897, in json
    return complexjson.loads(self.text, **kwargs)
  File "/opt/rh/rh-python36/root/usr/lib64/python3.6/json/__init__.py", line 354, in loads
    return _default_decoder.decode(s)
  File "/opt/rh/rh-python36/root/usr/lib64/python3.6/json/decoder.py", line 339, in decode
    obj, end = self.raw_decode(s, idx=_w(s, 0).end())
  File "/opt/rh/rh-python36/root/usr/lib64/python3.6/json/decoder.py", line 357, in raw_decode
    raise JSONDecodeError("Expecting value", s, err.value) from None
json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0)
```
This may be not the correct way to create secrets, as the `write` function didn't parse data correctly:
```
$ vault kv get secret/prod/Arthur
==== Data ====
Key     Value
---     -----
data    map[IP:192.168.1.4 Password:Pa$$w0rd User:root]
```
I expected something like:
```
==== Data ====
Key     Value
---     -----
IP    192.168.1.4
Password  Pa$$w0rd
User   root
```
This is maybe related to the `create_or_update_secret` issue, however I can't find the correct way to do it in the documentation.

items.body:
OK I upgraded to 9.5 and token auth suddenly became unsupported.

I'm going to likely stub out a token auth class to conform to this ridiculous undocumented breaking change to fix it but needing an auth class to support native features seems like a short sight.

curl -i -k -X POST -H 'X-Vault-Token: <redacted>' -d @azure-eng-config.json https://vaultexample.com:8200/v1/azure/config

read config

{"client_id":"<redacted>","environment":"","subscription_id":"<redacted>","tenant_id":"<redacted>"}
```

```
cat azure-eng-config.json
{
    "subscription_id": "<redacted>",
    "client_id": "<redacted>",

items.title: Cannot initialize Vault using recovery shares
items.body:
When initializing a Vault deployment configured with a `seal` stanza you are required to specify the `recovery_shares` and `recovery_threshold` values. The current logic make it impossible to initialize Vault in this configuration, as the code path the passes library's the argument checking logic will fail Vault's argument checking logic.

Current argument checking logic: `if recovery_threshold <= recovery_shares:`
Needed argument checking logic: `if recovery_threshold > recovery_shares:`

This logic bug was fixed in f8b7842f but was explicitly reintroduced in e3637383

prod_db: "{{ lookup('hashi_vault', 'secret=serverlab/production/db token=ce9c4734-4c71-971c-57d7-f5cd7240e860 url=https://127.0.0.1:8200 validate_certs=False')}}"

fatal: [192.168.1.107]: FAILED! => {"msg": "An unhandled exception occurred while templating '{{ lookup('hashi_vault', 'secret=secret/serverlab/production/db token=ce9c4734-4c71-971c-57d7-f5cd7240e860 url=https://127.0.0.1:8200 validate_certs=False')}}'. items.title: Unable to authenticate on AWS Lambda

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: documentation updates and/or requests for expanded documentation

items.body:
I was able to get HVAC authenticating successfully when running on an EC2 instance. However, I am seemingly not able to get the same code working on Lambda. Since I see a number of past issues relating to Lambda, as well as [examples in the docs](https://hvac.readthedocs.io/en/latest/usage/auth_methods/aws.html#lambda-and-or-ec2-instance), I assume this should be supported. However I suspect some of the examples may be slightly outdated. I'm wondering if perhaps something has changed?

Here's the main body of my Lambda function:

```python
import hvac
import logging
import os


logging.basicConfig()
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)
logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)


def handler(event, context):
    client = hvac.Client(url="https://vault.mydomain.com")
    client.auth_aws_iam(
        access_key=os.getenv("AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID"),
        secret_key=os.getenv("AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY"),
        session_token=os.getenv("AWS_SESSION_TOKEN"),
        header_value="vault.mydomain.com",
        role='my-vault-role',
    )

    secrets = client.read("secret/path/to/my/secrets")
    values = secrets.get("data")
    logger.info(values)
    return {"body": values}
```

The reason I said that the examples are slightly outdated is because they don't include `AWS_SESSION_TOKEN`, which AFAIK is always present on Lambda functions, these days.

The error message I get says **failed to verify `my-test-func` as a valid EC2 instance in region us-east-1**, but I'm not using EC2 authentication (I am using IAM authentication). Here's the stack trace:

```
failed to verify my-test-function as a valid EC2 instance in region us-east-1: InvalidRequest
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/var/task/lambda.py", line 18, in handler
    role='my-vault-role',
  File "/var/task/hvac/v1/__init__.py", line 638, in auth_aws_iam
    return self.login('/v1/auth/{0}/login'.format(mount_point), json=params, use_token=use_token)
  File "/var/task/hvac/v1/__init__.py", line 1191, in login
    **kwargs
  File "/var/task/hvac/adapters.py", line 177, in login
    response = self.post(url, **kwargs).json()
  File "/var/task/hvac/adapters.py", line 106, in post
    return self.request('post', url, **kwargs)
  File "/var/task/hvac/adapters.py", line 276, in request
    utils.raise_for_error(response.status_code, text, errors=errors)
  File "/var/task/hvac/utils.py", line 29, in raise_for_error
    raise exceptions.InvalidRequest(message, errors=errors)
hvac.exceptions.InvalidRequest: failed to verify my-test-function as a valid EC2 instance in region us-east-1
```

The weird thing is that if I run what is basically the same code, on an EC2 instance, it works fine. Specifically, this is the code that I have running on EC2:

```python
import hvac
import logging
import requests


logging.basicConfig()
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)
logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)


def load_aws_ec2_role_iam_credentials():
    # first get the IAM role we are currently operating under
    url = "http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/iam/security-credentials/"
    response = requests.get(url)
    response.raise_for_status()
    current_role = response.text

    # then look up STS credentials
    url = f"http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/iam/security-credentials/{current_role}"
    response = requests.get(url)
    response.raise_for_status()
    security_credentials = response.json()
    return security_credentials


creds = load_aws_ec2_role_iam_credentials()
client = hvac.Client(url="https://vault.mydomain.com")
client.auth_aws_iam(
    access_key=creds.get("AccessKeyId"),
    secret_key=creds.get("SecretAccessKey"),
    session_token=creds.get("Token"),
    header_value="vault.mydomain.com",
    role='my-vault-role',
)

secrets = client.read("secret/path/to/my/secrets")
values = secrets.get("data")
logger.info(values)
```

That code successfully prints out the secrets that I have set at that path. Both the Lambda and the EC2 code are running under the same role / instance profile. The only thing observably different about the code is how they retrieve their STS access keys, which is per the HVAC documentation. Since the error message says that it fails to verify my Lambda function as a valid EC2 instance, I'm wondering if I missed setting some kwarg or function call in HVAC?

It may also be worth noting that in this is a cross-account scenario. Vault lives in one account, whereas this code (both Lambda and EC2) live in a separate AWS account. I have roles set up on both sides which allows Vault to authenticate and validate my EC2 instances. Clearly, though, I know this setup works (just not on Lambda), as evidenced by the fact that my code on EC2 runs fine.

The cross-account role which Vault ultimately assumes has the following permissions: `ec2:DescribeInstances`, `iam:GetRole`, `iam:GetInstanceProfile`, and `iam:GetUser`. For good measure I just added in `lambda:ListFunctions`, though unfortunately that didn't solve the problem. Any ideas?

items.title: KV2 engine and restrictive policy leads to strange behaviour

labels.name: kv
labels.description: Key/Value (KV) secrets engine

items.body:
I have the following policy:

```JSON
"paths": {
(...)
        "secret/data/foo/bar/*": {
            "allowed_parameters": {
                "x": [],
                "y": [],
                "z": []
            },
            "capabilities": [
                "create",
                "read",
                "update",
                "delete",
                "list"
            ],
(...)
}
```

The following works fine: `vault write secret/data/foo/bar/baz x=1 y=2 z=3`.

However, using the same exact token in hvac:

```Python
>>> client.secrets.kv.v2.create_or_update_secret('foo/bar/baz', secret = {'x': '1', 'y': '2', 'z': '3'})
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/[REDACTED]/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/hvac/api/secrets_engines/kv_v2.py", line 122, in create_or_update_secret
    json=params,
  File "/home/[REDACTED]/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/hvac/adapters.py", line 106, in post
    return self.request('post', url, **kwargs)
  File "/home/[REDACTED]/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/hvac/adapters.py", line 276, in request
    utils.raise_for_error(response.status_code, text, errors=errors)
  File "/home/[REDACTED]/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/hvac/utils.py", line 33, in raise_for_error
    raise exceptions.Forbidden(message, errors=errors)
hvac.exceptions.Forbidden: 1 error occurred:
	* permission denied
```

I did a tcpdump (since it was to an HTTP Vault server on localhost), and found that the Vault CLI client does e.g. (real values have been replaced):

```
PUT /v1/secret/data/foo/bar/baz HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8200
User-Agent: Go-http-client/1.1
Content-Length: [REDACTED FOR DEMO]
X-Vault-Token: [REDACTED FOR DEMO]
Accept-Encoding: gzip

{"x":"1","y":"2","z":"3"}
```

BUT the client.secrets.kv.v2.create_or_update_secret call does e.g. this (actual values replaced):

```
POST /v1/secret/data/foo/bar/baz HTTP/1.1
Host: localhost:8200
User-Agent: python-requests/2.21.0
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
X-Vault-Token: [REDACTED FOR DEMO]
Content-Length: [REDACTED FOR DEMO]
Content-Type: application/json

{"options": {}, "data": {"x": "1", "y": "2", "z": "3"}}
```

Notable differences are a POST vs. PUT, and the structure of the payload.

For whatever reason, this causes a permission denied error (403) for hvac, but the vault client succeeds.

At a *guess*, maybe [the docs](https://www.vaultproject.io/api/secret/kv/kv-v2.html#create-update-secret) are wrong? As the Vault client does not seem to conform to the docs (but hvac does).

Are you able to replicate?

items.title: create_token does not support 'token_type'

labels.name: auth methods
labels.description: generally related to a Vault auth method

items.body:
Creating batch tokens (introduced for token_create in hashicorp/vault#755) requires a token_type parameter to be sent. https://www.vaultproject.io/api/auth/token/index.html#token_type

As of v0.7.2, v1.Client.create_token does not accept this argument.

items.title: parsing response from vault to useful python collection
items.body:
I'm having a problem parsing hvac responses, i dont think this is necessarily a problem with hvac but im wondering if anyones solved this problem before or has an eloquent recommendation because **i dont like my current solution.**

example response:
```
{u'lease_id': u'', u'warnings': None, u'wrap_info': None, u'auth': None, u'lease_duration': 0, u'request_id': u'81-scrambled-5f-c21b4844b75c', u'data': {u'keys': [u't1', u't2', u'tf/']}, u'renewable': False}
```
what i want to extract:
key_list = `['t1', 't2', 'tf/']`

**current working solution**
```
r = client.secrets.kv.v2.list_secrets('test', mount_point='secret')
key_list = ast.literal_eval(json.dumps(json.loads(json.dumps(r))[u'data'][u'keys']))
```

**Things i noticed**
typical solution:
```
key_list = ast.literal_eval(json.dumps(client.secrets.kv.v2.list_secrets('test', mount_point='secret'))).data.keys[:]
ERROR: 'malformed string'
```
the problem is that json.dumps() converts `None` and `False` to `null` and `false` which `literal_eval` cannot parse ("Error: Malformed string")


`ast.literal_eval()` alone wont work because it cannot parse the original unicode response "malformed string"

`key_list = json.dumps(r).data` wont work because r is now a `str` and not a `dict`

items.title: illegal base64 client.auth.gcp.login

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: documentation updates and/or requests for expanded documentation

labels.name: gcp
labels.description: Google Cloud Platform (GCP) auth method and/or secrets engine

items.body:
Trying to authenticate with Vault via GCP jwt. The code to generate the jwt is found here https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/python-docs-samples/blob/master/endpoints/getting-started/clients/google-jwt-client.py#L29
```python
import google.auth.crypt
import google.auth.jwt
import hvac

signer = google.auth.crypt.RSASigner.from_service_account_file(path_to_sa_json)
now = int(time.time())
expires = now + 3600  # One hour in seconds
payload = {
    'iat': now,
    'exp': expires,
    'sub': 'service-account@my-project.iam.gserviceaccount.com',
    'aud': 'vault/my-role'
}
jwt = google.auth.jwt.encode(signer, payload).decode('utf-8')

client = hvac.Client(url='vault.example.com', verify='path/to/ca.pem')
client.auth.gcp.login('my-role', jwt)
```

The call to `client.auth.gcp.login('my-role', jwt)` returns
```
hvac.exceptions.InvalidRequest: illegal base64 data at input byte 190
```

I did some more digging. If I take the `jwt` generated with the Python code above and run
```bash
vault write -field=token auth/gcp/login role=my-role jwt=<jwt-from-above>
```
I again get `illegal base64 data at input byte 190` but this time it's directly from Vault so I cut out the possibility that hvac is the problem.

Next I tried generating a jwt with `gcloud` via (near the bottom of https://cloud.google.com/solutions/using-vault-for-secret-management)
```bash
GOOGLE_PROJECT=$(gcloud config get-value project)
SERVICE_ACCOUNT=my-service-account@${GOOGLE_PROJECT}.iam.gserviceaccount.com
cat - > login_request.json <<EOF
{
    "aud": "vault/my-role",
    "sub": "${SERVICE_ACCOUNT}",
    "exp": $((EXP=$(date +%s)+600))
}
EOF
export JWT_TOKEN=$(gcloud beta iam service-accounts sign-jwt login_request.json \
    signed_jwt.json \
    --iam-account=${SERVICE_ACCOUNT} && cat signed_jwt.json)
```
Then I used that jwt to do
```bash
vault write -field=token auth/gcp/login role=my-role jwt=$JWT_TOKEN
```
and it worked!

So in the end the problem is not with hvac. It's in google or more likely my use of google's code being incorrect.

items.title: URL redirect partially broken in v0.6.1
items.body:
In v0.6.0  v1/__init__.py there was code:
```
  # NOTE(ianunruh): workaround for https://github.com/ianunruh/hvac/issues/51
        while response.is_redirect and self.allow_redirects:
            url = urljoin(self._url, response.headers['Location'])
            response = self.session.request(method, url, headers=headers,
                                            allow_redirects=False, **_kwargs)
```
If a redirect occurred then urlparse:urljoin was used.  In v0.6.1 urljoin was switched to an internally written function, that just joins strings with a slash. 
```
 @staticmethod
    def urljoin(*args):
        """
        Joins given arguments into a url. Trailing and leading slashes are
        stripped for each argument.
        """

        return '/'.join(map(lambda x: str(x).strip('/'), args))

```
We have a vault cluster where when you hit a non-master node, you get a fully qualified URL.  The new code then redirects to something like https://vault.my.org:8200/https://10.100.10.1:8200/.  The urljoin from url parse has more advanced parsing that looks at the string being appended and if the second string starts with https:// is just uses the second string.
The new code would work for a redirect to a page on same site, but fails on redirects to a new site.

This change appears intentional, but breaks us.  I don't know what this commit fixed:
https://github.com/hvac/hvac/commit/3f08b5f8d599fcf65aa2a4018337dedcac7f3429

items.title: Possible bug with `delete_role_secret_id_accessor`

labels.name: approle
labels.description: AppRole auth method

labels.name: auth methods
labels.description: generally related to a Vault auth method

items.body:
The https://github.com/hvac/hvac/blob/master/hvac/v1/__init__.py#L2064 `delete_role_secret_id_accessor` method does not look like the documented https://www.vaultproject.io/api/auth/approle/#destroy-approle-secret-id-accessor method in the API.

1) the docstring has `DELETE` instead of `POST`
2) the docstring has `/secret-id/` instead of `/secret-id-accessor`
3) both the code, and docstring do not have the `/destroy` suffix as per the API

Most probably it should be similar to `delete_role_secret_id` https://github.com/hvac/hvac/blob/master/hvac/v1/__init__.py#L2046 where `POST` and `/destroy` are used for `/secret-id/` endpoints, it also has the `{ "secret_id": "" }` param, also like the API documentation shows for the accessor destruction.

items.title: Occasional Failure of travis-ci Jobs
items.body: While the root cause is unknown at the time of this issue's creation, it is worth noting that travis-ci jobs for this repo occasionally fail waiting for the Vault server to start for integration tests. E.g.: https://travis-ci.org/hvac/hvac/jobs/443905728. They typically work upon a rebuild. The resolution may require increasing the time we wait for the Vault server processes to start to work around intermittent constraints on resources / etc. in a given CI/CD environment.

Expanded GCP auth method coverage. New Azure auth method and secret engine classes. Run test cases against multiple versions of Vault to ensure backwards compatibility. Documentation fixes / updates.

Note: was originally scoped as the 0.6.5 release. After missing the 2018/10/01 release date and with a few small backwards incompatible changes, this became a minor version bump to 0.7.0 instead.

items.body:
I don't see a way to do a "patch" operation which appends to a current key rather then overwriting it.   

vault kv put secret/test foo=bar

stores 
```
foo=bar
```

vault kv put secret/test foo=bar2 

stores
```
foo2=bar2
```
but
vault kv patch secret/test foo3=bar3

stores
```
foo2=bar2
foo3=bar3
```

so it appends rather then overwrites (as long as the key isn't the same).  

does HVAC have a way to support "patch" operations?

items.title: hvac.api.auth.github.Github : map_user() type mismatch

milestone.description:
Expanded GCP auth method coverage. New Azure auth method and secret engine classes. Run test cases against multiple versions of Vault to ensure backwards compatibility. Documentation fixes / updates.

Note: was originally scoped as the 0.6.5 release. After missing the 2018/10/01 release date and with a few small backwards incompatible changes, this became a minor version bump to 0.7.0 instead.

items.body:
For the method map_user() the suggested type for the parameter `policies` is a string, which should be a comma separated list of policies. But then you use a `",".join(policies)` in the code (line 141), suggesting that `policies` is actually a python list and not a string.

For example, if you read the documentation, you might think that you should set `policies` to : 
`policies = "policy_1, policy_2"` which is a string as required by the doc
But then the final value that is sent to vault would be : 
`"p,o,l,i,c,y,_,1,, ,p,o,l,i,c,y,_,2"`

Whereas if we set `policies` to : 
`policies = [policy_1, policy_2]` which is a list and not a string
The final value sent to vault would be `"policy_1,policy_2"` which is whats we want.

items.body:
It looks like the [API](https://www.vaultproject.io/api/system/auth.html#enable-auth-method) accepts a config map (similar to enable_secrets) for enabling an auth method, but the `enable_auth_backends()` method does not:

Expanded GCP auth method coverage. New Azure auth method and secret engine classes. Run test cases against multiple versions of Vault to ensure backwards compatibility. Documentation fixes / updates.

Note: was originally scoped as the 0.6.5 release. After missing the 2018/10/01 release date and with a few small backwards incompatible changes, this became a minor version bump to 0.7.0 instead.

items.body: This is referencing #243 which allows for overriding the `region` in the call to `auth_aws_iam`. It seems that setting the region to any value other than the default `us-east-1` results in an error. I am in region `eu-west-1`, but even using `us-west-1` fails: Here's quick snippet: ```python import boto3 import hvac VAULT_ADDR = os.environ["VAULT_ADDR"] VAULT_HEADER_VALUE = os.environ["VAULT_HEADER_VALUE"] AWS_DEFAULT_REGION = os.environ["AWS_DEFAULT_REGION"] session = boto3.Session() creds = session.get_credentials().get_frozen_credentials() client = hvac.Client(url=VAULT_ADDR) client.auth_aws_iam( creds.access_key, creds.secret_key, creds.token, region="us-west-1", header_value=VAULT_HEADER_VALUE, role=role, use_token=True, ) ``` The resulting stacktrace (below), and seems to indicate that something went wrong with the signature since it is a response from `AWS:STS` (unclear why it thinks that `us-west-1` is an invalid region though). I am suspecting that some hard-coded region is still lingering somewhere, but I can't seem to track it down. I'll keep looking though. ``` Traceback (most recent call last): File "lambda_function.py", line 112, in None, File "lambda_function.py", line 32, in lambda_handler vault_authenticate(header_value=VAULT_HEADER_VALUE) File "lambda_function.py", line 27, in vault_authenticate use_token=True, File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/hvac/v1/__init__.py", line 1153, in auth_aws_iam return self.auth('/v1/auth/{0}/login'.format(mount_point), json=params, use_token=use_token) File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/hvac/v1/__init__.py", line 1713, in auth **kwargs File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/hvac/adapters.py", line 159, in auth response = self.post(url, **kwargs).json() File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/hvac/adapters.py", line 103, in post return self.request('post', url, **kwargs) File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/hvac/adapters.py", line 233, in request utils.raise_for_error(response.status_code, text, errors=errors) File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/hvac/utils.py", line 29, in raise_for_error raise exceptions.InvalidRequest(message, errors=errors) hvac.exceptions.InvalidRequest: error making upstream request: received error code 403 from STS: Sender SignatureDoesNotMatch Credential should be scoped to a valid region, not 'us-west-1'. 12d83688-aaf1-11e8-a3f0-8f815ba4c0eb ``` Importantly, this snippet works fine: ```python import boto3 import hvac VAULT_ADDR = os.environ["VAULT_ADDR"] VAULT_HEADER_VALUE = os.environ["VAULT_HEADER_VALUE"] AWS_DEFAULT_REGION = os.environ["AWS_DEFAULT_REGION"] session = boto3.Session() creds = session.get_credentials().get_frozen_credentials() client = hvac.Client(url=VAULT_ADDR) client.auth_aws_iam( creds.access_key, creds.secret_key, creds.token, header_value=VAULT_HEADER_VALUE, role=role, use_token=True, ) ```

items.title: Client.unwrap missing client token error
items.body:
The Client.unwrap function should not pass the cubbyhole token in the request body, as Vault now expects it in the header. The workaround is to set the cubbyhole token as the client token.

This produces an error:
```
vc = hvac.Client()
unwrapped = vc.unwrap(<cubbyhole_token>)
```

Workaround:
```
vc = hvac.Client()
vc.token = <cubbyhole_token>
unwrapped = vc.unwrap()
```

items.title: Integration Tests Should Reset State Between Test Cases
items.body:
Relying on test cases to both 1.) verify the dev Vault instance is in an appropriate state to run and 2.) ensure they've reset the state of things after running assertions can:

* Make it harder to jump in and write a new test case (due to the implicit knowledge needed to write one "correctly" within the current scope of how things are configured).
* Opens us up to unexpected side-effects and test failures that are unrelated to the actual logic under test.

We should reset the state of the dev Vault cluster during setUp/tearDown (or something similar) as much as possible.

items.title: Silently fails when the vault address contains routes
items.body:
`urljoin` on line 1471 silently drops trailing routes on the Vault URL and fails, even though the URL is valid and works fine with the vault binary. 

Example: 
```
url = urljoin(`https://my.cloud.com/vault/`, '/v1/auth/token/lookup')
print(url)
# => https://my.cloud.com/v1/auth/token/lookup
```

Note that this works as expected with the vault command line binary:

```
export VAULT_ADDR=https://my.cloud.com/vault/
vault status
...
# what you expect to see
```

I'm sure using `urljoin` has benefits, but silently rewriting my URL in a case where Vault itself has no problem is a little off-putting.

Vault is hosted on a subroute because its sitting behind a reverse proxy via nginx, in order to share the system with other services on one server, domain, and one SSL config. Nginx rewrites the route when proxying and removes the `/vault`, of course.

items.title: Document Examples of Access Key Retrieval for AWS IAM Auth Usage

milestone.description:
Expanded GCP auth method coverage. New Azure auth method and secret engine classes. Run test cases against multiple versions of Vault to ensure backwards compatibility. Documentation fixes / updates.

Note: was originally scoped as the 0.6.5 release. After missing the 2018/10/01 release date and with a few small backwards incompatible changes, this became a minor version bump to 0.7.0 instead.

items.body:
[Moving this discussion from https://github.com/ianunruh/hvac/pull/155#issuecomment-400119225 into an issue for visibility. cc: @RevolutionTech]

re: https://github.com/ianunruh/hvac/pull/170

Sorry if this is a stupid question, but since the API in https://github.com/ianunruh/hvac/pull/170 now requires an access key ID and a secret access key, is there any way we can use IAM auth without having those at runtime? For the application I work on, we store those credentials in Vault currently.

I realize that we can infer credentials with `boto3` using the following code:
```python
import boto3
session = boto3.Session()
credentials = session.get_credentials()
print(credentials.access_key, credentials.secret_key)
```
but boto3 [attempts to collect](https://boto3.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/configuration.html) the access key and secret key from many different locations (such as environment variables, and from `~/.aws/credentials`) before it ultimately uses the IAM role, so if we were to rely on this we may not collect the credentials that correspond to the IAM role we want.

Is there some other way to extract an access key and secret key from an IAM role that I'm missing?

items.title: Ensure All Tests Pass with Latest Vault Version (v0.10.2)
create_ec2_role Should Explicitly Send auth_type Parameter Generally
items.body:
In newer versions of Vault / the AWS auth backend plugin, the https://www.vaultproject.io/api/auth/aws/index.html#create-role route has parameters that apply to both IAM and EC2 auth_types. For this module's existing `create_ec2_role()` method, we should also send auth_type="ec2" with our requests. This is to avoid the following type of failure:

> hvac.exceptions.InvalidRequest: specified bound_iam_role_arn but not specifying ec2 auth_type or inferring ec2_instance

items.title: Add mount_point Parameters for All AWS (EC2 / aws-ec2) Methods
items.body: Much like https://github.com/ianunruh/hvac/issues/178, we should avoid making assumptions about the path / mount_point of the AWS auth backend. Additionally, presumably after those methods were initially added, the AWS EC2 and AWS IAM auth backends were merged into a singular backend and the current documentation leads to a default path / mount_point of just "aws".
